The uvula hangs from the soft palate, the fleshy bit behind the roof of your mouth,

So that's good.
It does this by covering up your nasal passage just as your chomped-up sandwich passes by.
Parts of the soft palate produce a thick, gloopy kind of saliva to help the food go down,

The inside of the uvula is packed full of glands that can quickly make large amounts of thin, watery saliva.
These glands are connected to muscle fibers that run through the uvula.

where sleep is interrupted by parts of the throat cutting off airflow at night.
The repetitive stress of each snore might be what makes the uvula so inflamed.
A swollen uvula is unpleasant.
